The Pallof Press is an anti-rotation core exercise that primarily targets your obliques, transverse abdominis, rectus abdominis, and glutes to prevent your torso from twisting, working isometrically to resist the band's pull. The key movement pattern is resisting spinal rotation, teaching your core to stabilize the spine, with secondary muscles like deltoids, triceps, lats, traps, rhomboids, and erector spinae acting as stabilizers to maintain a rigid, upright posture as you press out and return the band. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Core: Obliques (internal & external), Transverse Abdominis, Rectus Abdominis (maintains core rigidity). 
• Stabilizers: Glutes (especially gluteus maximus), Erector Spinae, Lats, Scapular Stabilizers (traps, rhomboids). 
• Upper Body (Secondary): Deltoids, Triceps, Rotator Cuff muscles (shoulder stability). [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Pattern: Anti-Rotation 

• Goal: To actively resist unwanted rotation of the trunk. 
• Action: You press the band/cable straight out from your chest (or higher, depending on variation) while your core muscles contract powerfully to prevent your body from turning towards the anchor point. 
• Key: Maintain a stable spine, keeping hips and shoulders aligned, avoiding arching your back or shrugging. 
• How it Works: The resistance band creates a rotational force, and your core muscles work isometrically (without changing length) to counteract it, building functional strength for real-world movements. [1, 2, 5, 8, 9, 10, 11]  

Variations (Changing the Challenge) 

• Half-Kneeling: Easier, good for beginners. 
• Standing: Harder, requires more core and glute engagement. 
• Staggered Stance (Split Stance): Increases stability demand. 
• Overhead: Adds shoulder stability and challenges core bracing under load. [1, 5, 10, 12, 13]
